1734 (aka 08-T-062) and 1768 (aka 08-T-097) combined provisionals from 1734 and 1768 for PCT filing under 1734; per Carla email 9/25/2019 12:12PM

INACTIVATED THIS CASE FOR THE REASON BELOW
From: Heather Bakalyar 
Sent: Sunday, September 29, 2019 10:33 AM
To: Carla L Bradshaw <cbradshaw@uchicago.edu>; Su Jun Lim <sujunlim@UCHICAGO.EDU>
Cc: Eric Ginsburg <ginsburg@uchicago.edu>
Subject: RE: GSK License Agreement - Technology Grouping (AND A NEW INACTIVATION - Just want to review the license info before requesting action)

Hi all,

I “Related” the following cases in Inteum:

-	1306, 1424 (combined technologies under 1306)
-	1734, 1768 (combined Provisional’s from 1734 and 1768 for PCT filing under 1734)
-	1800, 1850, 1851 (combined technologies under 1800)

and noted the information Carla provided corresponding to each member of each combination under the “Comments” section in the IP tab.

Note: 

For 2 of the three groupings, all cases were kept active after the combining occurred.  However, for one combination (1734, 1768), one of the pair (1734) was inactivated.  No status date is given for that case.  I’m assuming it was inactivated when the (apparent) decision was made to allow all the 1734 filings go abandoned.  A little background:  it appears after the final rejection in the US, we stopped prosecution in the US and at that point allowed all the issued patents in foreign jurisdictions to go abandoned.

I believe we should consider inactivating 1768 as it was combined into the now inactive 1734 has no active patent filings.  It is currently in “Exclusively Licensed” status.

Regards,
Heather

Title: Use of Modified DNAzymes for RNA Knockdown and Applications Thereof
Division/Department: Biological Sciences Division (BSD), Comprehensive Cancer Center, Lab Alex Ruthenburg 2-74595, Molecular Genetics and Cell Biology
Comments:
3/11/2020 Disclosure form updated to reflect 1/24/2020 as disclosure date per CF request. -SJ

3/3/2020 - For time line purposes 
Shakira,

Here is a technology description for this invention disclosure.  It would be great to get this into Inteum so we don’t lose track of it.

Deoxyribozymes (DNAzymes) are DNA sequences having catalytic activities. DNAzymes have several advantages over ribozymes or protein enzymes. They are chemically and biologically more stable than ribozymes and protein enzymes, allowing ease in handling and storage. DNAzymes are readily prepared and modified. DNAzymes of the 10-23 type are catalytically active nucleic acids that cleave complementary RNA molecules in a sequence-specific manner, therefore have many potential uses. The inventors' design incorporates a thymine to uracil mutation in the catalytic core of the 10-23 DNAzyme for improved stability. 

Thanks,
Cristi

Title: Use of RecA protein to detect DNA molecules.
Division/Department: Biological Sciences Division (BSD), Comprehensive Cancer Center, Lab Douglas Bishop 6-33217, Radiation and Cellular Oncology
Comments:
Circled back with Dr. Bishop on 10/13/2020 phone call re decision not to patent.  According to his recollection, he was aware we were not patenting.  773-230-1542


Hello Dr. Bishop,

It was great to meet you today!

I’ve attached a patent, US5861244. 

 It was of interest to me b/c in one embodiment, it attached a ssDNA to an anchor of some kind.  Weakly bound to that anchored ssDNA is a ssDNA with a sequence of interest, I will call it the probe.  The probe has a label attached, and can additionally be attached to a protein that facilitates formation of triple strands.  

The opeartor then will flush double stranded DNA pieces across the anchor. The patent does not call for the pieces to be the product of an amplification process, but the use is similar.  As the DNA pieces flush through, those that have complementary sequence to the probe will form that triple strand and displace the probe from its weakly attached/anchored DNA.  Then, the label is measured in the eluant.

Sorry such a bad writeup (it’s a bit late!) but hopefully I described it well enough to give the gist.

I’ll have my co-worker (not Thelma, a PhD candidate ready to defend her thesis) do a second patent search just to be thorough, and we will circle back with you.

Best,
Heather and Thelma

HAB from email:
From: Preeti Chalsani 
Sent: Wednesday, June 10, 2020 2:27 PM
To: Jacob Lissoos <jlissoos@UCHICAGO.EDU>
Subject: Notes from Chong Meeting June 10, 2020

Jake,
Here are my notes from the meeting.
Lets talk soon, let me know when you have a chance.
Thanks,
Preeti

Discussion with Chong and Eli – June 10, 2020
Method for membrane fabrication is novel – drying and rewetting process for preparation that makes the defects disappear
-	Process of self assembly where defects will damage performance, if you do not control assembly process, you end up with huge defects which renders performance bad, no defects gives you huge flux, need to control larger size defects
-	Control how hydrated membrane is, first get rid of larger defects by drying, after you get rid of water and get rid of defects, control how much water coming back which determines layer spacing
-	Rejection higher than what others have, although flux may not be state of art magnitude
Others tried to eliminate voids by applying large pressure (external compressions)
Here – internal compressions by controlling wetting, benefit is that it can be done during prep of membrane and store dry, instead of doing during testing and having to keep it moist.
External pressure can get rid of defects but not clear how much improvement you can get.
Rejection rate is  function of type and conc of salt , if you control type and conc of salt, we achieve highest rejection for higher concentrations (others lower conc and higher rejection or lower rejection for higher concentration)
Need to compare same type of salt.
Desalination targets higher conc, sea water would be even higher than what they have measured, chong’s conc is for brackish water.

Size of defects characterized in SEM. (Fig. 3), others have larger defects. Perhaps membrane can be distinguished by physical features as well

Manuscript sent to reviewers now, 1 or 2 weeks for reviewer comments.

From: Heather Bakalyar 
Sent: Tuesday, August 13, 2019 5:46 PM
To: nuriel@medicine.bsd.uchicago.edu
Subject: RE: touch base "HVAD Waveform as a surrogate marker of cardiac index and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure" UCHI# 16-T-043

Hello Dr. Uriel,

I don’t mean to bother you, I know you are busy!  I’ll just give a quick update on your case "HVAD Waveform as a surrogate marker of cardiac index and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure" UCHI# 16-T-043.

Medtronic/Heartware had been interested in this invention.  In fact, they signed a time-limited option agreement so that they could evaluate its commercial opportunity without fear that another company would license it.  However, after much thought and discussion, Medtronic/Heartware has decided not to pursue this particular invention any farther.  Though the company does not want to license this invention, its representatives wanted to ensure we understood that it remained interested in your and your work.

Usually, my office limits its patent filings to the United States.  However, in certain circumstances (e.g. like if a company is interested in the invention), my office will file in other countries as well.  That is what happened with your invention – the office filed in China and Europe, in addition to the United States.

Europe has rejected the patent application we filed there.  The combination of that rejection with Medtronic/Heartwave’s decision not to move forward has pushed my office to stop its patent prosecution efforts in Europe.  Without Medtronic/Heartwave’s interest, it will likely do the same for China.

However, at this point we do wish to keep the patent application in the US alive and see if we can find another potential licensee.

Please feel free to call or email me if you would like more information on this invention.  And certainly, please call or email me if you have other discoveries in your lab.  I would welcome the opportunity to learn more about what you do.

With thanks,
Heather

Heather –

It looks like you may hear from Dr. Uriel after all, but know that HeartWare continues to support this effort either way.  If there is new data to add and no evidence of a public disclosure, option #1 is probably best unless you think you have time to work the new data into a non-provisional application.  If there is no new data to add (and won’t be), perhaps Option #2 is the way to go.  In our experience, it would be more difficult to file a non-provisional now if we need to add data to it down the road.  

In any event, no matter which of the two options makes the most sense to you after speaking with Dr. Uriel (or not), know that Medtronic HeartWare is still very much supportive of this effort and will pay the prosecution and maintenance costs pursuant to the agreement.

As discussed, once we’re through this fire drill, perhaps we could schedule some time to get us smarter about this project and next steps.

Thanks again,

Mark

Market to Sterlitech:

Good afternoon, Sepideh,

I reached out to you via LinkedIn earlier this month with a University of Chicago technology that I thought might be of interest to Sterlitech.  It is a simple apparatus and method for transferring thin polymer films with a highly reduced rate of defects.  

The invention is described in detail in the attached publication.  The publication also points to a video.  If you are interested in seeing the video but cannot access, I can arrange to use something like dropbox to get it to you.

University of Chicago has until June 2019 to file a US patent application on the apparatus and method.  If it is of interest to your company, and it is something your Sterlitech might want to in-license and exclude competitors from making/using/selling, please let us know.  We would be happy to start a dialogue.

With regards,
Heather

Heather Bakalyar, Ph.D., M.B.A., patent agent
Technology  Commercialization
Polsky Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation 
University of Chicago
5113 S. Harper Ave, Suite 2C, Chicago IL 60615

Email: hbakalyar@uchicago.edu
Office: (773) 702-8833


Sterlitech response: Thank  you Heather, what membrane diameters can this apparatus be built in? Can this be scaled up? what types of applications or use cases do you foresee for this product? HAB to ask inventors.

Seth Darling says: There is no obvious limit to the membrane diameter for this invention.  One could fabricate a drain chamber customized for nearly any size membrane.  It may be that when membranes become very large, the meniscus of the water in the chamber will no longer keep the transfer layer centered, but we have no evidence for this.

Regarding use cases, the fabrication of composite membranes with ultrathin selective layers on top of porous supports is a common practice in the research community.  It may turn out to have industrial applications as well, down the line.

_________________________
Market to Millipore

From: Heather Bakalyar 
Sent: Monday, November 4, 2019 1:08 PM
To: James Hoberg <james.hoberg@milliporesigma.com>
Cc: Preeti Chalsani <pchalsani@uchicago.edu>
Subject: UChicago invention -- device to transfer thin polymer films

Hi Jaime,

We have a University of Chicago invention on our dockets that might be of licensing interest to Millipore.

The invention is described in detail in the attached publication.   Its a simple apparatus and method for transferring thin polymer films with a highly reduced rate of defects.  There is no obvious limit to the membrane diameter for this invention, and we believe one could fabricate a drain chamber customized for nearly any size membrane. 

The invention is of immediate use to the research community as fabrication of composite membranes with ultrathin selective layers on top of porous supports is a common practice.  We believe this invention will have industrial applications as well, down the line.

University of Chicago has until June 2019 to file a US patent application on the apparatus and method.  If it is of sufficient interest to Millipore for in-licensing and excluding US competitors from making/using/selling, please let us know.  We would be happy to start a dialogue.

With best regards,
Heather

correspondence
 
Miss Bakalyar, 
 
Thank you for meeting with me today. I appreciate your time and guidance through this process!
 
Initially I had developed my own sheets and process for patient self recording of their own intake & output. We had trialed the sheets and process on 10 E for about a month.
 
With a team of a 10 E nursing assistant, another nurse, our Certified Nurse Specialist, and myself we further adjusted the process and utilized Health Literacy to create more formal sheets.  
 
Below are the final forms developed that were developed by our 10 E team & Health Literacy at UCMC.
 
At the moment our team is about to apply for a Quality Improvement Project for the sheets and process. I will forward the application for further detail on this Intake & Output project.  
 
I will also forward the email from Nutrition Services to further the gap on where this App could come into play now.
 
Please let me know what the next steps are or if there are any other questions you have for me. 
 
Again, thank you for your time and guidance. I hope you have a great week!

Somewhere in URA files, found a document that included the below.  It could explain how Yun Fang was not on the grant but is an inventor.

Dr. Myung Oh, who is a postdoc under the mentorship of Dr. Yun Fang, is resubmitting an AHA
Postdoc Fellowship grant due this Thursday (7/12/18). AHA limits stipend to the NIH years of
experience and fringe to $1,000/year, so we need to cost share the difference between this amount
and true cost of salary/fringe benefits for Dr. Oh. I’ve attached a budget and cost sharing memo for
$28,671 over two years. I’m also attaching AHA guidelines. It looks like Dr. Fang’s development
account was identified as the source of this cost sharing previously. Please let me know if you have
any questions/concerns or if this has your approval.
__________________________________

11/15/2019.  See Documents.  In an email (uploaded), Yun Fang notes that the AHA funding was NOT used for this invention.  It was used for the earlier invention related to artherosclerosis (18-T-282).  He forgot to remove the funding on this invention disclosure, where he used the older one as a base.  Heather remembers seeing the 18-T-282 invention disclosure but it is no longer in the record (???).  Would like to have that in hand when go to AHA to explain that this invention 19-T-090 was not made with AHA.

Comments:
Original tech analysis of this invention is uploaded (see documents, upload on 10/31/2019).  January 14, 2020 inactivation email uploaded on 1/26/2020.  

During several months of review discussing Rima's 2019 invention disclosures with her, it appeared the only novel thing about this disclosure was the formulation.  By her own admission, Rima had just thrown together 11 Disclosures (8 unique, only 5 were entered into our systems b/c some where so deficient -- e.g. even missing a title in addition to actual data) in a rush and solely for the purpose of keeping us appraised of what was happening in your lab, consistent with the note in 18-T-209 Assessment (see excerpt below). She appears to have changed her mind and wanted Polsky to patent.   I added the data and manuscript she provided to her Disclosure so the record would be clear that we were passing on all of it, so if she wishes to patent she will have good title.  (I made her aware that if she does not reasonably disclose something to us, we can't give it back to her).  Uploaded in three parts.19-T-133w-revised-manuscript.


Cut and past from 18-T-209 tech assessment.
We haven't been able to find a market for toxoplasmosis treatment, let alone prophylaxis. (Repeated) market feedback from companies is the major factor in play
Dr. McLeod is aware that we've tried and failed to find receptive partners willing to develop interventions in toxoplasmosis. She no longer expects us to take action on her developments, but does a general scientific update periodically. We try to help her with company interactions when we can (CDAs that don't generally lead to any licensing inquiries).


5 documents uploaded on 1/28/2020 correspond to the finalized version of the manuscript Rima submitted to Nature.
